bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.C. Geiger, March 6, 1919

div1.p: Carter informs Geiger of his upcoming research on the relation between rice cultivation and malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.C. Geiger, March 6, 1919
div1.opener:
/LC
Mal
Geiger
March 6, 1919.
Dr. J. C. Geiger, Assistant Epidemiologist,
U. S. Public Health Service,
City Hall Building,
Little Rock, Ark.
Dear Doctor Geiger:
div1.p:
I congratulate you on your Doctorate of Public Health. I
am sure you deserved it and very sure that your future work will
make Tulane proud of her son.

I am still afraid you have taken too ambitious a program.
It is a good plan to concentrate on something and complete it so
that no one else will ever have to do any more work on it.

I judge that your problem is “The Relation of Rice Culture
to the Incidence of Malaria,” and its object is to try to find
methods economically practicable for its control, or at least for
minimizing it. If that be the case, you should lay yourself out
on the questions pertaining to it and stress nothing else. It
will take at least three years more I judge. I don't mean that
you will not keep your eyes open and pick up all the data bearing
on other malarial problems incidentally, but it will be incident-
ally--the other your object.

I am inclined to think it would be a good plan to have more
than one of your sub-divided rice plats--say--100 to 200 yds. apart.
-2-
You will have to draw your deductions as to control of mosquito
production from these plats and three or four are none too many:
something may happen to one--as the hog got in at Lonoke. Having
several there is no reason that they should be so large or have
so many divisions, but I think it will pay you to scatter your plats.

As this is all the experimental field work you have planned--
although you may be compelled to do some other incidentally--
it will pay you to develope it. I contrast experimental field work
with the field observations that you will make.

Observations on flight will be among the most important you
will make--and keep the expressions: “of sanitary importance: of
no sanitary importance” in your mind all the time. The number of
imagoes produced or found at a place or in a residence is of prime
importance--I mean whether a few or many. I don't mean to count
them.

You might keep your eyes open for data on what is--I think--
the most important field problem for the U. S. yet unsolved,
namely: the proportional degree to which the differenct species of
Anopheles are, in nature, vectors of malaria. It is not a ride
culture problem. however, so only look into it if you have a chance
incidentally. You remember how we had it planned in the program
I sent you about Christmas; or do you?

However, the object of this letter is to advise you to con-
centrate--i. e. “not to bite off more than you can chew.”

Seek advice--don't necessarily follow it. Get the opinions
of others--don't necessarily adopt them.

I had a series of field problems written out in 1917 in the
-3-
spring, which are good to keep in mind. I will write to Miss Riva
and ask her to send you a copy.

Learn all you possibly can as to the kind of breeding places
of the different species. Amen.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
